On 11/29/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
>
> On 30/11/05, C=
=C3=A9dric Beust =E2=99=94 <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > Why work on it if=
 the testing framework can do it for you?
> >
> > Without dependent methods=
:  "10 FAILURES".
> >
> > With dependent methods:  "1 FAILURE, 9 SKIPS".
> =
>
> > I know which result I prefer :-)
>
> They both say the same thing to =
me: I've got something that, if it is
> broken, affects lots of tests.


No=
t quite, because "10 FAILURES" might mean that there are really ten broken
=
tests, or that there is one broken and nine that failed because that first
=
one failed.  Or the break down could be 2/8.  Or 3/7.  Or...  you get the
i=
dea.

Over the years, I have learned to mistrust the results that JUnit giv=
es me
for that reaon.  I read "10 FAILURES" and deep inside, I know that "n=
ah,
it's not really ten failures".

And it's so easy for the testing framew=
ork to provide accurate reports if it
gets a little help from the developer=
...

--
C=C3=A9dric
